keyTakeaways: Quantum mechanics challenges our intuitions about reality at the fundamental level
The double-slit experiment reveals wave-particle duality and the measurement problem
Multiple interpretations exist: Copenhagen, Many-Worlds, Pilot Wave—each with tradeoffs
Quantum mechanics has been experimentally verified to extraordinary precision
The relationship between observer and observed remains philosophically puzzling
summary_short: Cao Tianyan tells the thrilling story of quantum mechanics—from Planck's reluctant discovery to the ongoing debates about what it means. Through vivid narrative, he makes accessible one of physics' most counterintuitive theories, showing how it upended our understanding of reality.
summary_medium:
Why This Book Matters

Quantum mechanics is notoriously difficult to understand—not mathematically, but conceptually. Cao Tianyan wrote this Chinese bestseller to make the history and philosophy of quantum theory accessible to general readers.

The Revolution Begins

Planck, Einstein, Bohr, Heisenberg, Schrödinger—the founders of quantum mechanics were often uncomfortable with what they discovered. Reality at the smallest scales defied common sense.

The Interpretation Problem

What does quantum mechanics mean? The Copenhagen interpretation says don't ask. Many-Worlds says every possibility exists. Pilot Wave theory restores determinism. None is fully satisfying.

Living with Mystery

Quantum mechanics works—it's the most precisely tested theory in science. But its meaning remains disputed. Perhaps some mysteries can be used without being solved.
